title: 109_hr4422
content: The Act titled "Safeguarding Explosives for Homeland Security Act" aims to prevent unauthorized access to explosive materials stored by state or local agencies. The "Safeguarding Explosives for Homeland Security Act" requires each State to report on the locations, types, and amounts of explosive materials stored by agencies under State law. Initial reports must be submitted within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with subsequent updates as specified by the Attorney General. Regulations governing the storage of explosive materials must also be established within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General will prescribe final regulations for the storage of explosive materials by State or local agencies within months of the Act's enactment. The regulations will outline safety standards, including video surveillance or alarm systems. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect these storage locations during business hours. The Attorney General will impose penalties for noncompliance with regulations on storing explosive materials by State or local agencies. Penalties include reducing grant funds by 10% for noncompliant agencies, with reallocation of funds to compliant agencies. SEC. 3. MATCHING GRANTS. (a) Application.--A State or local agency may submit an application for a grant under this section to the Secretary of Homeland Security, including a cost estimate for compliance with regulations and a certification of funding commitments. (b) Grant Authority.--The Secretary may award a grant if the application meets requirements. The grant applicant must submit all required reports to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The grant amount cannot exceed half of the application total. The grant must be used for complying with regulations. $10,000,000 is authorized for grants without a fiscal year limit. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "explosive materials" is defined as in section 841(c) of title 18, United States Code. The term "agency" excludes any component of the National Guard. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia.
